project_name: CLARE BRUBACHER 108'-0" X 188'-0" DAIRY GOAT BARN
location: 083777 Southgate Rd. 08, Mt. Forest, ON N0G 2L0
gravity_system: Pre-Engineered Trusses, Loadbearing Walls, Continuous Footings
other_materials: Plywood, Metal Siding, Rigid Insulation, Housewrap
key_elements: Shearwalls, Milking Parlour, Manure Storage Pad, Manger Curb, Awning, Truss Lateral Bracing
overall_building_description: The structural design of the Clare Brubacher Dairy Goat Barn integrates a robust framework of pre-engineered scissor trusses spaced at 4'-0" on center, providing a primary load path for roof loads to be transferred efficiently to the loadbearing walls and continuous footings. The roof system is further reinforced with 29ga metal roof cladding and 2x4 strapping at 24" o.c., ensuring lateral stability and diaphragm action. The trusses are supported by a combination of HSS steel columns and wood stud walls, with shearwalls providing lateral resistance against wind and seismic forces. The shearwalls are constructed with 7/16" OSB sheathing, fastened with 2 3/8" nail-gun nails at 4" o.c. along panel edges and 8" o.c. in the field, with blocking at 24" o.c. and 3-ply stud posts at each end, as detailed in 2/S3. The foundation system comprises 25 MPa concrete walls and footings, with reinforcement detailed as per the foundation schedule. The footings are designed to bear on undisturbed soil, with a minimum bearing capacity of 3000 psf, ensuring adequate support for the superstructure. The foundation walls include a 10" sandwich wall with 2" rigid insulation, providing thermal efficiency while maintaining structural integrity. The connection details, such as the steel beam to stud post connection, utilize 3/8" endplates with A325 bolts, ensuring a secure load transfer between elements. The barn's layout includes specialized areas such as the milking parlour, which features a 6" thick suspended slab of 32 MPa concrete, reinforced with 15M rebar at 12" o.c. each way, providing a durable and hygienic surface for dairy operations. The manure storage pad, a critical component for waste management, is constructed with a 6" thick concrete floor, reinforced with continuous 15M bars, and detailed with a slope for efficient drainage. The barn's design also incorporates environmental considerations, such as vented soffits and attic fire stops, ensuring compliance with fire safety regulations and enhancing ventilation. The use of pre-engineered trusses and standardized connection details facilitates efficient fabrication and assembly, reducing construction time and costs. The project specifications emphasize the use of high-strength materials and precise construction techniques, ensuring the barn's longevity and performance under various operational conditions. The integration of advanced engineering principles and meticulous attention to detail in the design and construction of the Clare Brubacher Dairy Goat Barn exemplifies a commitment to quality and functionality in agricultural building design.
